title: Erdős Problem #135: Four Points, Five Distances
description: If any 4 points from A ⊂ ℝ² determine at least 5 distinct distances, must A determine ≫ n² distances? DISPROVED by Tao (2024).

overview.historicalContext: Erdős conjectured that local constraints on 4-point configurations would force global distance diversity. Tao disproved this in 2024 as part of his exploration of erdosproblems.com.
overview.problemStatement: Let A ⊂ ℝ² be n points such that any 4 points determine at least 5 distinct distances (out of 6 possible). Must A determine ≫ n² total distinct distances?
overview.proofStrategy: Tao uses randomized algebraic curves over finite fields. Parabolas (ax+by)² ≡ cx+dy+e (mod p) naturally avoid parallelograms. Random affine transformations and probabilistic deletion handle other forbidden 4-point patterns. The result: O(n²/√(log n)) distances with the five-distance property.
keyInsights: Four points have 6 pairwise distances; the 'five-distance property' requires ≥ 5 distinct
Parallelograms have only 2-3 distinct distances and must be forbidden
Points on parabolas automatically avoid parallelograms (algebraic constraint)
Random affine transformations reduce other forbidden patterns
The construction achieves O(n²/√(log n)) distances - subquadratic but not by much

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #135 is DISPROVED. Tao (2024) constructed n-point sets with the five-distance property but only O(n²/√(log n)) distinct distances, disproving the Ω(n²) conjecture.
conclusion.implications: Local constraints on 4-tuples don't imply global distance diversity. The √(log n) factor matches Guth-Katz bounds, suggesting this is optimal.
openQuestions: What is the exact optimal bound for five-distance sets?
Can the construction be made deterministic?
What about higher dimensions or different forbidden patterns?
